title: European Fisheries Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1198/2006 on the European Fisheries Fund, as regards certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability
background: The European Fisheries Fund faced underutilization due to Member States' financial constraints from the 2008 economic crisis and austerity measures, limiting national cofinancing capacities. Institutional reviews highlighted challenges in accessing funds for eligible projects. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to adjust financial management provisions for states experiencing fiscal instability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the Commission’s proposal to enhance EFF accessibility for Member States experiencing financial instability, aligning perfectly with EPP’s commitment to equitable resource distribution in fisheries-dependent regions.  
EPP approves the urgency of adopting these amendments at first reading to accelerate critical support for modernizing vessel safety standards and reducing environmental impacts, consistent with EU sustainability goals.  
EPP applauds the issue’s focus on financial stability mechanisms, which effectively advance EPP’s priority of ensuring operational flexibility for underfunded coastal communities.  
EPP proposes strengthening reprogramming provisions to better address localized needs, such as integrating multifunctional fisheries development and downstream economic activities highlighted in Parliament’s recent issues.  
EPP emphasizes the opportunity to expand credit guarantee frameworks for private cofinancing, ensuring optimal EFF utilization while maintaining strict adherence to fiscal responsibility principles.

EFD supports accelerating EFF payment mechanisms to mitigate economic pressures on small-scale fishermen while maintaining sustainable fisheries management goals.  
EFD advises enhancing fund accessibility for coastal communities through simplified administrative procedures and reduced national co-financing requirements.  
EFD recommends explicit safeguards to prevent EFF liquidity support from becoming unconditional bailout subsidies, aligning with fiscal responsibility principles.  
EFD emphasizes the need for crisis-response flexibility in fisheries funding while urging parallel reforms to reduce long-term CFP regulatory burdens on operators.  
EFD expresses concern about insufficient differentiation between emergency liquidity provisions and structural investment needs in the amended regulation's financial architecture.

ALDE strongly sanctions the enhanced co-financing measures, aligning perfectly with their commitment to economic recovery through targeted fisheries sector support.  
ALDE approves the retroactive application timeline as effectively advancing liquidity needs for maritime communities in austerity-programme countries.  
ALDE endorses the first-reading adoption process, demonstrating institutional responsiveness to urgent financial stabilization requirements.  
ALDE proposes monitoring the 2012–2013 implementation period to ensure adequacy for full economic recovery objectives.  
ALDE commends the issue’s alignment with EU treaty frameworks, reinforcing their principle of inter-institutional accountability in crisis management.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s solidarity measures, aligning with their commitment to sustainable fisheries and addressing youth unemployment through enhanced fund accessibility for crisis-affected Member States.  
SD applauds the increased co-financing flexibility, which effectively advances coastal community development and aligns with their priorities for sustainable resource management in Mediterranean and Black Sea regions.  
SD endorses the focus on simplifying fund execution procedures as a critical enhancement opportunity to ensure timely utilization of allocated resources while maintaining rigorous financial oversight.  
SD highlights the necessity of regional cooperation frameworks, such as the proposed Black Sea consultative forum, to strengthen ecosystem-based management practices consistent with long-term fisheries sustainability goals.  
SD commends the issue’s alignment with cohesion policy objectives, particularly in mitigating austerity impacts by channeling €207 million towards job creation and sectoral modernization in vulnerable economies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the European Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0484) at first reading without amendments, endorsing its substantive content related to fisheries policy. It emphasized the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending substantial revisions or replacements, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural continuity. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate the adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional dialogue and adherence to EU treaty frameworks. No numerical data or specific policy changes were introduced, as the resolution primarily affirmed the Commission’s original text.

title: European Maritime and Fisheries Fund: REPORT on the amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1198/2006 and Council Regulation (EC) No 861/2006 and Council Regulation No XXX/2011 on integrated maritime policy
background: The European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (2014-2020) was proposed to replace prior EU fisheries financing instruments, aligning with reforms to the Common Fisheries Policy addressing overfishing, fleet sustainability, and maritime integration. The Parliament will discuss the fund’s structure, funding priorities, and compliance with updated sustainability and resource management objectives.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue's alignment with sustainable fishing practices, particularly its focus on eliminating discards and promoting selective fishing gear to achieve maximum sustainable yield.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly include temporary scrapping aid for fleet reduction, ensuring alignment with regionalized PPC implementation while maintaining strict anti-overcapacity safeguards.  
EPP approves modernization support for small-scale coastal fisheries under 12 meters, urging amended Annex III to increase funding caps for engine upgrades addressing environmental compliance without capacity expansion.  
EPP endorses expanded aquaculture provisions, recommending modified Clause 29(b) to allow controlled non-native species cultivation where proven environmentally sustainable and economically vital for coastal communities.  
EPP emphasizes the need to strengthen youth entrepreneurship programs in Chapter 7, mirroring agricultural sector models to ensure generational renewal in fisheries-dependent regions.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally rejects the proposal's failure to prohibit public subsidies enabling fleet overcapacity, directly contradicting their demand for fisheries aligned with marine ecosystem limits.  
GREEN_EFA opposes allocating funds for vessel construction and engine upgrades as perpetuating destructive overfishing practices explicitly condemned in their parliamentary interventions.  
The issue conflicts with GREEN_EFA's principle that EU funds must prioritize scientific stock assessments and enforcement capabilities over business transfer payments criticized as "blank checks".  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of binding safeguards against using public money for illegal fishing activities, a core concern raised during the CFP reform debates.  
This proposal overlooks critical opportunities to redirect resources toward small-scale sustainable fisheries and youth training programs advocated by Verts/ALE speakers.

ALDE strongly sanctions the EMFF's alignment with sustainable fisheries management, particularly endorsing targeted decommissioning schemes to reduce fleet overcapacity as demonstrated by Ireland's successful model.  
ALDE approves enhanced funding for aquaculture development in Natura 2000 areas, recognizing this as critical to maintaining 90% of EU maritime economic activity while proposing stricter sustainability criteria to prevent ecological harm.  
ALDE advocates redirecting vessel construction subsidies toward data collection and stakeholder training programs, enhancing the issue's effectiveness in combating overfishing through evidence-based resource management.  
ALDE emphasizes strict parliamentary oversight of funds allocated for discard management systems, ensuring producer organizations fulfill their responsibilities under the reformed Common Fisheries Policy.  
ALDE proposes amending Article 12 to explicitly prohibit public financing for inactive fishing permits, transforming this criticism into a transparency enhancement that preserves budgetary integrity.

GUE/NGL firmly conflicts the issue's restrictive definition of small-scale fisheries, which contradicts their documented advocacy for realistic categorization supporting artisanal fishing communities.  
GUE/NGL rejects the prohibition on funding new local landing ports, a policy that neglects critical infrastructure needs in member states and disproportionately harms small-scale fishers.  
The proposal fails to address recurring maritime fatalities, ignoring GUE/NGL's demands for safety investments like storm-resistant harbors or vessel upgrades.  
This framework perpetuates regional disparities in fisheries management, inconsistent with GUE/NGL's principle of equitable resource allocation across diverse EU maritime economies.  
 While acknowledging improved co-funding rates for biological data, GUE/NGL maintains the overall structure inadequately supports sustainable small-scale fisheries.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning multiple policy areas, including fisheries, employment, environment, public health, and regional development, as outlined in the Commission’s original (COM(2011)0804) and amended (COM(2013)0245) proposals. The resolution emphasized alignment with Treaty provisions on transport, energy, industrial policy, and external action, while integrating opinions from committees on budgets, social affairs, environment, and regional development. It formally adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to uphold parliamentary oversight by re-submitting the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements were planned. The resolution underscored procedural adherence by instructing the President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring coherence across EU policies and legal frameworks.

title: External dimension of the common fisheries policy: REPORT on the external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy
background: The EU, a major global fishing actor and fish product importer, operates under international agreements and regional fisheries bodies while addressing overexploitation, illegal fishing, and sustainability challenges. The Parliament will discuss the external governance of fisheries policies, including partnerships, resource management, and coherence with trade and development objectives.

stances.stance:
EFD partially supports the issue’s emphasis on small-scale fisheries but requests revisions to mandate stricter enforcement of Mediterranean stock recovery plans, citing systemic non-compliance with existing regulations.  
EFD supports traceability schemes to combat IUU fishing but demands an explicit amendment requiring shark fins to remain naturally attached to carcasses, closing loopholes exploited by certain Member States.  
EFD highlights contradictions in the issue’s reliance on EU-wide agreements, arguing it fails to address jurisdictional gaps that allow foreign fleets to bypass national bans on practices like finning near sovereign waters.  
EFD requests revisions to tie sectoral funding for third countries to verifiable labor standards, noting the issue’s development goals are inconsistent with current permit systems enabling exploitative practices.  
 While endorsing climate-resilient Arctic management, EFD opposes centralized RFMO enforcement as undermining domestic sovereignty over coastal fisheries.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue's stringent measures against IUU fishing, particularly banning shark finning by mandating fins remain naturally attached, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to marine species protection.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the alignment of Sustainable Fisheries Agreements with scientific stock assessments and sustainability objectives, effectively advancing their priority of ecosystem-based fisheries management as outlined in the Lövin report.  
GREEN_EFA approves the prioritization of small-scale fisheries and equitable coastal community benefits, reflecting their advocacy for integrating artisanal fishing into sustainable food security frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing decentralized decision-making for technical fisheries measures to regional authorities, ensuring adaptability while maintaining the issue's ecological standards.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes strict adherence to human rights and ecological standards for EU fleets operating globally, aligning perfectly with their commitment to social justice in international agreements.

ALDE supports the issue's IUU fishing measures but proposes stricter traceability requirements for third-country imports to match EU standards.  
ALDE advises modifying SFAs to mandate direct involvement of local fishing communities in agreement monitoring.  
ALDE recommends amending Article 9 to explicitly prohibit EU subsidies for vessels previously engaged in flag-switching practices.  
ALDE endorses the small-scale fisheries focus but urges binding targets for Member States to allocate 25% of access rights to coastal artisanal fleets.  
ALDE suggests enhancing climate resilience provisions by linking RFMO reforms to IPCC marine ecosystem projections.

GUE_NGL partly advocates the issue’s sustainability framework but demands binding clauses to redirect fisheries agreements from financial transfers to capacity-building for third countries’ autonomous resource management, as current provisions risk perpetuating extractive practices.  

GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s insufficient mechanisms to ensure equitable wealth distribution, insisting on mandatory reinvestment of sectoral support into coastal communities’ infrastructure and small-scale fisheries to align with anti-neocolonial principles.  

GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to impose equivalent ecological standards on EU fleets operating abroad, requiring amendments to penalize destructive practices like bycatch mismanagement that contradict EU domestic regulations.  

GUE_NGL criticizes the issue’s weak linkage between market access and labor rights enforcement, urging explicit bans on imports from fisheries violating ILO standards to address systemic exploitation in partner countries.  

GUE_NGL supports shark finning prohibitions but underscores the need for satellite monitoring mandates for all EU vessels to prevent circumvention, as self-reporting mechanisms proposed lack rigor to protect endangered species.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over global overfishing, noting that 85% of assessed fish stocks are fully or overexploited, and emphasized the EU’s responsibility as the world’s largest importer of fishery products (24% by value) and a major fishing actor. It called for aligning the external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) with sustainability, human rights, and development goals, stressing the need for Sustainable Fisheries Agreements (SFAs) to ensure surplus resource access under UNCLOS, prioritize scientific stock assessments, and decouple financial compensation for access from sectoral support for third countries. The resolution urged stricter enforcement of IUU fishing regulations, including traceability schemes, sanctions for non-compliance in RFMOs, and market measures to block unsustainable products. It highlighted the importance of transparency in bilateral agreements, equitable benefits for coastal communities, and support for small-scale fisheries, while demanding EU fleets adhere to ecological and social standards equivalent to those in EU waters. The Parliament also advocated for stronger RFMOs, climate-resilient Arctic fisheries management, and coherence between trade, development, and environmental policies, including WTO negotiations to curb harmful subsidies and promote fair labor practices.

title: Arrangements for importing fishery and aquaculture products into the EU with a view to the future reform of the CFP: REPORT on the arrangements for importing fishery and aquaculture products into the EU with a view to the future reform of the CFP
background: The EU, the world's largest fishery and aquaculture market, faced declining domestic production, over 60% import dependence, and projected demand growth of 1.5 million tonnes by 2030. The Parliament will discuss import arrangements amid preparations for reforming the Common Fisheries Policy to address market sustainability and trade dynamics.

stances.stance:
EPP supports requiring imported fishery products to meet equivalent EU health and environmental standards to maintain fair competition for European coastal communities and aquaculture sectors.  
EPP advises amending WTO agreements to classify fisheries products as sensitive goods under Special and Differential Treatment provisions, exempting them from industrial NAMA tariff reduction mandates.  
EPP proposes transferring exclusive negotiation authority for fisheries trade chapters from DG Trade to DG Maritime Affairs to prioritize stock conservation over broad market access agendas.  
EPP highlights concerns about fragmented Commission leadership, urging binding inter-service agreements between trade and fisheries policymakers to align import rules with CFP sustainability goals.  
EPP urges stricter origin certification protocols in trade deals to prevent third-country processing loopholes that undermine EU tuna fleets and enable labor abuses.

GREEN_EFA supports the issue’s emphasis on leveraging EU market power to enforce global sustainability standards but stresses the need for enhanced support to developing countries’ fisheries governance.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening the IUU Regulation by establishing an EU-funded technical assistance program to improve traceability systems and combat certification fraud in high-risk regions.  
GREEN_EFA urges binding implementation of the FAO Code of Conduct through bilateral trade agreements, with compliance tied to preferential EU market access.  
GREEN_EFA highlights vulnerabilities in self-certification mechanisms and advocates for regional third-party verification taskforces to ensure documentation integrity.  
GREEN_EFA recommends allocating 10% of CFP external funding to modernize surveillance technologies in small island states disproportionately affected by illegal fishing.

ALDE supports the issue’s sustainability objectives but advises amending trade agreements to include binding import reduction targets (66% to 50% over 10 years) with progress reviews.  
ALDE proposes streamlining bureaucratic hurdles in EU fisheries management to align import controls with competitiveness goals for domestic producers.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for mandatory origin labeling to empower consumer choice, noting this omission in current health standard provisions.  
ALDE endorses strict equivalence checks for third-country environmental and social standards, reinforcing the issue’s anti-illegal fishing measures.  
ALDE welcomes recognition of peripheral regions’ economic vulnerabilities in amendments but urges explicit funding mechanisms in CFP reform.

ECR slightly upholds the market organization framework but demands structural revisions to align with fishermen's operational realities, noting divergence from sustainable resource management principles.  
ECR opposes the Commission's imposition of individual transferable quotas, advocating instead for the report's alternative approaches to preserve coastal community economies.  
ECR highlights inadequate enforcement provisions in developing nations, insisting the issue must specify capacity-building mechanisms for health standard compliance.  
ECR rejects the current WTO safeguards formulation, requiring explicit exemptions for fishery products under NAMA industrial trade rules.  
ECR identifies critical gaps in private sector integration, urging amendments to expand aquaculture import control roles for industry stakeholders.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the EU's position as the world's largest market for fishery and aquaculture products, valued at €55 billion and 12 million tonnes in 2007, while noting its growing reliance on imports due to a self-sufficiency rate below 40% and projected demand increases of 1.5 million tonnes by 2030. It emphasized sustainable management of fish as a renewable resource to prevent stock depletion and protect coastal communities globally, urging strengthened international fisheries governance and trade rules. The resolution called for the EU to leverage its role as the top importer to promote high environmental and social standards in WTO and FAO agreements, ensuring trade aligns with sustainability and poverty reduction. It advocated treating fish as sensitive products under WTO rules, exempting them from industrial NAMA frameworks, and applying safeguards to balance trade with conservation. The Parliament stressed that all imports must meet EU health standards and supported measures against illegal fishing, including the EU’s regulation to block illegally caught fish, while recognizing the need to assist developing countries in compliance and enforcement efforts.

title: A catch documentation programme for bluefin tuna (thunnus thynnus): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a catch documentation programme for bluefin tuna Thunnus thynnus and amending Regulation (EC) No 1984/2003
background: Critically depleted bluefin tuna stocks due to overfishing and illegal trade prompted international conservation efforts through ICCAT, with repeated scientific warnings about unsustainable catch levels. High market demand, particularly in Asia, exacerbated unregulated fishing despite existing controls. The Parliament will discuss implementing enhanced catch documentation requirements to improve traceability and combat illegal fishing practices.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the catch documentation programme as vital to combat illegal fishing but advises reinforcing Article 7 with satellite tracking mandates for small vessels to prevent certificate fraud.  
EFD recommends amending Annex II to replace the 1974-derived 6.4 kg minimum catch weight with science-based size limits ensuring juvenile protection.  
EFD highlights the issue’s failure to prohibit fishing during breeding seasons and urges adding seasonal closures in Article 9 to safeguard reproductive cycles.  
EFD advocates integrating consumer awareness campaigns into the regulation’s implementation, promoting scrutiny of tuna sourcing in retail markets.  
EFD cautions that reliance on self-reporting by remote fleets risks loopholes, proposing third-party verification protocols in Article 4(b) for enhanced traceability.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the catch documentation programme as essential for combating illegal fishing and preventing species extinction, aligning with their commitment to marine biodiversity preservation.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue's emphasis on parliamentary oversight, which advances their priority of transparent, science-based fisheries governance in line with precautionary ecosystem management.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the traceability mechanisms in Articles 2-4 as a critical step toward enforcing sustainable quotas and halting overexploitation of bluefin tuna stocks.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Section 7 to accelerate stock recovery timelines by mandating biannual independent population assessments, enhancing the programme's responsiveness to ecological thresholds.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that this framework aligns with their manifesto goals by treating bluefin tuna conservation as a benchmark for broader resource stewardship in an era of ecological scarcity.

SD strongly promotes the establishment of traceability measures to combat illegal bluefin tuna fishing, aligning with ICCAT recommendations for sustainable resource management.  
SD applauds the use of Lisbon Treaty provisions to delegate conservation powers to the Commission, enhancing dynamic adaptation to evolving sustainability needs.  
SD proposes strengthening enforcement capacities by allocating additional resources to the Vigo Control Agency for direct monitoring authority beyond coordination roles.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of proactive international engagement with CITES to prevent future extinction risks, addressing delayed action on depleted stocks.  
SD urges stricter penalties for Member States permitting flags of convenience enabling illegal fishing, closing regulatory loopholes undermining trade bans.

ECR supports the catch documentation programme’s emphasis on scientific rigor as foundational to sustainable fisheries policy, echoing the issue’s alignment with conservation goals under Article 43(2).  
ECR advises amending Article 7 to allocate increased funding for pan-European stock assessments, addressing gaps exemplified by fluctuating Baltic cod quotas, ensuring research consistency across all regional fisheries.  
ECR recommends expanding the programme’s scope to mandate standardized data collection methodologies in all EU waters, preventing fragmented implementation that could compromise policy coherence.  
ECR highlights concerns that under-resourced research frameworks risk repeating past inaccuracies, urging the Commission to integrate binding budgetary commitments for scientific agencies in Annex II.  
ECR stresses the need for periodic review clauses in Article 5 to adapt catch limits dynamically, ensuring alignment with evolving ecological data and avoiding static quota-setting errors.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning fisheries, adopting its first reading stance and urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacement of the proposal are intended. It emphasized procedural adherence under the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, particularly Article 43(2) on fisheries conservation measures, and instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The resolution aligned with the Committee on Fisheries’ report (A7-0119/2010) and referenced prior Commission communications, including COM(2009)0406 and COM(2009)0665, which addressed post-Lisbon Treaty procedural implications. While no specific numerical data were detailed, the resolution focused on maintaining interinstitutional accountability and ensuring parliamentary oversight in legislative revisions.

title: A new impetus for the Strategy for the Sustainable Development of European Aquaculture: REPORT on a new impetus for the Strategy for the Sustainable Development of European Aquaculture
background: The European aquaculture sector operates under fragmented regulations, with global sector growth outpacing EU production. As a net importer facing environmental and market challenges, the EU seeks to address competitiveness and sustainability. The Parliament will discuss strategic measures to enhance sustainable aquaculture development within the European Union.

stances.stance:
EFD requests revisions to Article 7's harmonization framework to explicitly permit national bans on intensive aquaculture methods in ecologically sensitive river systems.  
EFD slightly upholds eco-labeling provisions but demands amendment to Section 4.2 requiring public disclosure of medication types and quantities per production cycle.  
EFD objects to the issue's promotion of offshore expansion without binding impact assessments on migratory fish species, contradicting their biodiversity protection principles.  
EFD fundamentally condemns with the issue's presumption of aquaculture's lower environmental impact, citing unresolved nutrient pollution thresholds in Chapter 3.  
EFD requires modification of Annex II funding criteria to prioritize closed-containment systems over traditional coastal farms, aligning with their river protection stance.

GREEN_EFA supports the issue's prioritization of herbivorous fish farming and animal welfare improvements as critical steps toward reducing ecological impacts on marine ecosystems.  
GREEN_EFA advises replacing the proposed mandatory EU eco-labelling system with robust origin labeling tied to strengthened environmental legislation to avoid certification complexity.  
GREEN_EFA endorses regulatory harmonization but cautions against centralizing governance, urging respect for regional frameworks like Scotland’s locally adapted aquaculture strategy.  
GREEN_EFA advocates reallocating 30% of European Fisheries Fund resources to support circular water systems and native species replenishment in vulnerable coastal regions.  
GREEN_EFA stresses the need for binding criteria on feed sustainability in Article 4 to prevent indirect pressure on wild fish stocks from piscivorous aquaculture.

ECR partly agrees the issue's job creation goals but requests revisions to replace EU-wide harmonization with regional adaptation frameworks, particularly for climate-vulnerable areas like the Baltic.  
ECR firmly condemns the issue's regulatory consolidation approach as inconsistent with their anti-bureaucracy principles, citing existing 400+ regulations as excessive.  
ECR rejects the premise that centralized quality controls ensure competitiveness, arguing current import practices undermine EU producers without WTO action.  
ECR requests deletion of provisions expanding environmental constraints in coastal zones, advocating instead for streamlined national permitting systems.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to address parallels with failed fisheries policy centralization, demanding explicit safeguards against similar outcomes.

GUE_NGL strongly advocates the allocation of dedicated funding for SMEs and organic aquaculture, aligning with their commitment to equitable rural development and sustainable production.  
GUE_NGL strongly endorses stringent import controls and WTO advocacy to uphold public-health standards, consistent with their opposition to trade liberalization that undermines local producers.  
GUE_NGL approves the emphasis on research into indigenous species and disease prevention, crucial for ecological balance and long-term sector viability.  
GUE_NGL proposes enhancing eco-labelling by mandating public certification bodies to ensure transparency and avoid cost burdens on small producers.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s environmental safeguards in coastal zones as vital to reconciling aquaculture with biodiversity goals under Natura 2000.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for a harmonized EU legislative framework to address the fragmented and inconsistent regulations governing the aquaculture sector, which currently lead to market distortions and operational confusion. It emphasized aquaculture’s strategic importance in enhancing food security, reducing pressure on wild fish stocks, and supporting rural and coastal economies through job creation and sustainable production. The resolution called for consolidating existing regulations into a single legal text, prioritizing research, innovation, and technology transfer to improve competitiveness, and allocating dedicated funding under the European Fisheries Fund—particularly for SMEs, organic production, and eco-friendly practices like water purification systems. It stressed the need for stringent quality controls, eco-labelling to distinguish EU products, and traceability standards to ensure consumer trust, while advocating for humane animal welfare practices, including stress reduction during transport and slaughter. The Parliament highlighted challenges from non-EU competitors with lower environmental and labor standards, urging stricter import controls and WTO advocacy to uphold EU quality norms. It also addressed conflicts with environmental policies, advocating for sustainable coexistence with Natura 2000 areas, and solutions for space constraints through offshore aquaculture. Additional measures included vocational training, support for native species replenishment, and mitigating damage from cormorants via population management plans. The resolution underscored the sector’s lower environmental impact compared to other industries and called for public awareness campaigns to counter misconceptions, alongside promoting organic aquaculture through EU-wide labeling and feed sustainability criteria.

title: EU-Morocco Fisheries Partnership Agreement: protocol setting out fishing opportunities and financial contributions: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol between the European Union and the Kingdom of Morocco setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Morocco
background: The EU and Morocco’s Fisheries Partnership Agreement, revised after the 2011 European Parliament rejection of its previous protocol, addresses fishing access and financial terms in waters including Moroccan-administered Western Sahara, amid unresolved territorial sovereignty and international law concerns. The Parliament will discuss the agreement’s compliance with sustainability, economic terms, and legal obligations.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the protocol's alignment with international law and sustainable fishing practices, emphasizing improved cost-benefit ratios for EU fleets.  
EPP advises stricter monitoring of financial contribution allocations to ensure transparency in Western Sahara development projects as per Article 6 requirements.  
EPP endorses job creation benefits for EU and Moroccan workers, particularly highlighting stabilized employment for 800 Spanish fishing families.  
EPP recommends expanding observer access to joint committee meetings to verify compliance with human rights clauses during implementation.  
EPP acknowledges the need for a full evaluation of sectoral support outcomes before new negotiations, aligning with parliamentary oversight demands.

GREEN_EFA rejects the protocol as fundamentally illegal under international law, given Morocco’s lack of sovereignty over Western Sahara’s resources and the exclusion of Sahrawi self-determination in negotiations.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the agreement for normalizing human rights violations, citing Morocco’s refusal to include explicit references to Western Sahara or permit independent monitoring of Sahrawi conditions.  
This totally doubts with GREEN_EFA’s position that EU partnerships must prioritize consent of affected populations, as the Sahrawi people explicitly opposed the protocol without consultation.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding human rights clauses, which are diluted compared to other EU fisheries agreements, enabling unchecked exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the timing of the vote on Human Rights Day as hypocritical, aligning with Morocco’s disregard for Sahrawi dignity and UN-recognized rights to autonomy.

SD partly agrees the protocol’s environmental safeguards on pelagic species but demands binding amendments to exclude Western Sahara waters entirely until Sahrawi consent is formally obtained through UN-mediated consultations.  
SD requests revisions to Article 6 implementation by mandating real-time public disclosure of Morocco’s sectoral support expenditure reports, countering opacity risks in occupied territories.  
SD challenges the human rights suspension clause’s enforceability, citing Morocco’s documented suppression of Sahrawi dissent as irreconcilable with the party’s anti-occupation principles.  
SD insists on embedding independent EU observers in joint committee meetings to verify compliance with territorial benefit-sharing, addressing accountability gaps in the current draft.  
 SD rejects the economic prioritization of European artisanal fleets’ access without proportional guarantees for Sahrawi-led fisheries development, deeming this inconsistent with equitable partnership tenets.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the protocol's inclusion of Western Sahara waters, which violates international law and UN issues on territorial sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL opposes the agreement's legitimization of Morocco's occupation, drawing parallels to Indonesia's illegal exploitation of Timor-Leste's resources as condemned historical precedent.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to address the hypocrisy of EU human rights clauses given Morocco's documented oppression in Western Sahara.  
GUE_NGL condemns the Commission's disregard for the International Court of Justice ruling, making the protocol incompatible with anti-colonial principles.  
GUE_NGL demands exclusion of occupied territories from all agreements, mirroring the U.S. approach, to align with self-determination obligations under Article 6 monitoring.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to conclude the fisheries protocol with Morocco, which outlines fishing opportunities and financial contributions under their partnership agreement, while emphasizing the need for transparency and accountability. It insisted on Parliament’s right to timely and comprehensive information on the protocol’s implementation, including access to joint committee meetings as observers, documentation on objectives and indicators for Morocco’s fisheries sector support, and all relevant data to monitor compliance with Article 6, notably Morocco’s final report on the sectoral support program. The resolution reiterated demands for the Commission to submit a full evaluation of the current protocol’s outcomes and functioning to Parliament before negotiating any new agreement, ensuring informed oversight. The Parliament also instructed its leadership to communicate this position to EU institutions, member states, and Moroccan authorities.

title: EU-Morocco fisheries partnership agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol between the European Union and the Kingdom of Morocco setting out the fishing opportunities and financial compensation provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Kingdom of Morocco
background: The EU-Morocco Fisheries Partnership Agreement, governing access to Moroccan waters including Western Sahara, required renewal under Lisbon Treaty provisions. Concerns over sustainability, resource management, and economic viability arose from prior implementation. The Parliament will discuss concluding a new protocol setting fishing opportunities and financial compensation terms under the partnership agreement.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the provisional protocol to maintain fishing access and EU-Morocco cooperation, stressing its role in supporting Morocco's democratic reforms and mutual economic benefits.  
EPP advises enhancing scientific oversight in the new agreement to ensure ecological sustainability, including third-party stock assessments for pelagic fisheries.  
EPP emphasizes revising fund allocation transparency measures to mandate quarterly public reports on sectoral support disbursements to Moroccan coastal communities.  
EPP acknowledges concerns about limited parliamentary scrutiny in the current protocol but views extension as strategically vital during regional instability.  
EPP underscores strict adherence to international law regarding Western Sahara's status, urging explicit territorial application clauses in future negotiations.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally condemns the protocol's disregard for Western Sahara's self-determination, as it illegally treats Moroccan-occupied waters as sovereign territory.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the economic framework that prioritizes EU vessel access over local ecological limits, noting the €36.1 million compensation structurally enables resource exploitation rather than sustainable development.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the authorization of 100 EU vessels to harvest already overfished stocks, directly contradicting the party's principle of "exploitation of surplus stocks only" outlined in marine conservation policies.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's failure to require documented consent from Sahrawi representatives, making it inconsistent with precedents like the EU's stance on Timor-Leste during Indonesian occupation.  
GREEN_EFA demands immediate cessation of all fisheries agreements involving Western Saharan resources until UN-supervised consultations with the occupied population occur.

SD partially promotes the protocol extension to maintain EU-Morocco relations but requests revisions to Article 4 ensuring fishing quotas align with independent scientific assessments of stock sustainability.  
SD absolutely challenges with the current compensation structure, demanding amendments to allocate ≥50% of sectoral support directly to Western Sahara coastal communities under UN oversight.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding environmental safeguards, requiring insertion of penalty clauses for overfishing by EU vessels in Moroccan waters.  
SD rejects the protocol’s tacit endorsement of Morocco’s Western Sahara claims, insisting on a new Annex explicitly excluding Sahrawi territorial waters until self-determination is resolved.  
 While acknowledging employment benefits for 800 EU workers, SD highlights contradictions in prioritizing short-term jobs over depleted fish stocks violating SD’s 2021 Ocean Resilience Manifesto.

GUE_NGL rejects the protocol's inclusion of Western Sahara waters, as it violates international law by recognizing Moroccan sovereignty over a non-self-governing territory without Sahrawi consent.  
GUE_NGL opposes the financial compensation structure, citing independent evaluations showing no measurable benefits to Moroccan fisheries or coastal communities despite €20 million annual sectoral support.  
GUE_NGL condemns the agreement's failure to engage Sahrawi representatives, directly contradicting UN issues requiring consultation with peoples of non-self-governing territories.  
GUE_NGL challenges claims of sustainable fishing practices, noting depleted fish stocks and ecological damage documented in external assessments of previous agreement implementations.  
GUE_NGL demands immediate exclusion of Western Saharan waters from all EU-Morocco agreements, aligning with their stance against resource exploitation in occupied territories.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of a Fisheries Protocol between the EU and Morocco, which establishes fishing opportunities for EU vessels in Moroccan waters and outlines financial compensation. It linked IUU fishing to transnational organized crime, advocating Interpol involvement and alignment with the UN Convention on Transnational Organized Crime. The resolution highlighted support for developing countries through technical aid, Fisheries Partnership Agreements, and trade measures like suspending preferences for non-compliant states. It called for integrating IUU combat into EU external policies, prioritizing ocean governance at the 2012 UN Sustainable Development Summit, and leveraging market-state responsibility to close global IUU trade networks, ensuring coherence between trade, environmental, and development policies.

SD perfectly aligns with the call for maintaining EU development funds to strengthen Comoros' fisheries governance, transforming past shortcomings into opportunities for enhanced technical capacity-building.  
SD fully agrees leveraging trade restrictions as pressure for reforms, reflecting SD's principle of linking market access to verifiable sustainability progress in partner states.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to protect Comoros' unique biodiversity, including coelacanth populations, through intensified EU scientific cooperation—a priority mirrored in the issue’s ecological safeguards.  
SD underscores the issue’s alignment with SD’s 2030 Agenda framework, particularly its demand for Comoros to fulfill flag-state obligations while ensuring EU accountability for past partnership inefficiencies.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s recognition of IUU fishing’s devastating impacts but urges amendments to prioritize capacity-building over punitive measures for Comoros’ artisanal fishers.  
GUE_NGL advises redirecting EU funds from conditional fisheries agreements to direct support for local cooperatives, ensuring resources reach communities most affected by depleted stocks.  
GUE_NGL calls for binding provisions to prevent EU fleets displaced from Comorian waters from exploiting Mayotte and Réunion’s marine zones, citing ecological risks.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions in the EU’s approach by noting unchecked illegal Brazilian fishing in French Guiana, demanding consistent enforcement of IUU rules globally.  
GUE_NGL stresses that future agreements must prohibit industrial fleets’ access to territorial waters until coastal states gain full scientific and surveillance capacities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the termination of the EU-Comoros Fisheries Partnership Agreement due to the Comoros' persistent failure to combat illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing, despite being issued a "red card" in 2017 for inadequate flag state control and lack of corrective measures. The resolution highlighted that IUU fishing depletes global fish stocks (noting 26 million tonnes caught illegally annually, 15% of global catches), threatens marine ecosystems, undermines coastal communities' livelihoods, and exacerbates poverty in developing countries like the Comoros, where EU financial support (€600,000 annually, half earmarked for sustainable fisheries) failed to yield tangible improvements in monitoring, scientific capacity, or technical training over 30 years of cooperation. Parliament stressed the need for the Comoros to fulfill obligations under international law and the 2030 Agenda’s Sustainable Development Goal 14 (marine conservation), urging continued EU support through development funds to strengthen governance, surveillance, and local fisheries while maintaining pressure via trade restrictions until reforms are implemented. It called for future reengagement if the Comoros addresses IUU deficiencies, emphasizing multilateral cooperation, equitable resource sharing, and alignment of EU policies with global sustainability efforts to protect marine biodiversity and artisanal fishers.

title: A new CFP: structure for technical measures and multiannual plans: REPORT on a new CFP: structure for technical measures and multiannual plans
background: The 2013 Common Fisheries Policy reform introduced sustainability objectives, landing obligations, and regionalization, but faced challenges from fragmented technical measures across regulations and institutional tensions over decision-making powers. The Parliament will discuss structuring technical measures and multiannual plans to align with sustainability goals, balancing regional adaptation and regulatory simplification.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's framework to unify fragmented technical measures through regionalized approaches, aligning with EPP's commitment to simplifying EU fisheries governance while maintaining ecosystem-based management.  
EPP proposes enhancing stakeholder consultation mechanisms in Article 6 to systematically integrate small-scale fishers' operational knowledge, ensuring measures like gear selectivity rules avoid past errors such as the disproportional driftnet ban.  
EPP approves the emphasis on EMFF-funded innovation for selective fishing gear, which directly advances EPP's priority of modernizing fisheries without compromising environmental targets.  
EPP endorses the call to accelerate multiannual plans with MSY targets, urging the Commission to prioritize socio-economic impact assessments for coastal communities as highlighted in Seán Kelly's intervention.  
EPP recommends amending Recital 22 to explicitly recognize sustainable aquaculture's role in conservation, reflecting Hungary's closed-system fisheries model cited by Norbert Erdős as a best practice.

SD completely sanctions the issue’s binding alignment with maximum sustainable yield targets, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to science-driven fisheries governance and long-term ecological stability.  
SD perfectly supports the rejection of Council exemptions exceeding scientific advice, reflecting SD’s unwavering stance against short-term compromises threatening marine ecosystems and coastal livelihoods.  
SD strongly affirms the issue’s integration of Marine Strategy Framework Directive principles, advancing SD’s vision for legally coherent ocean conservation frameworks.  
SD unreservedly backs regionalized technical measures developed through Advisory Councils, recognizing this as essential for SD’s stakeholder-driven approach to sustainable fisheries.  
SD champions the issue’s emphasis on EMFF-funded gear innovation, seeing this as critical to achieving SD’s dual goals of ecological resilience and fishing community viability.

ECR strongly sanctions regionalized technical measures, aligning perfectly with ECR's commitment to subsidiarity and preserving traditional fishing communities' livelihoods.  
ECR approves the issue's push to simplify fragmented regulations through a unified EU framework, effectively advancing legal clarity and administrative efficiency.  
ECR proposes amending technical measure studies to comprehensively include Mediterranean fisheries and prioritize EMFF funding for regions disproportionately affected by economic austerity.  
ECR endorses stakeholder engagement via Advisory Councils as critical for balancing ecosystem-based management with socioeconomic stability.  
ECR welcomes stricter IUU enforcement measures as vital to safeguarding Mediterranean fish stocks and lawful fishing practices.

GUE_NGL rejects the centralized decision-making framework under Article 43 TFEU, totally disapproveing with their demand for member state-led proximity management to safeguard fisher livelihoods and coastal communities.  

GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s EU-wide uniformity in technical measures, which fails to address regional fishery diversity and artisanal practices critical to equitable resource conservation.  

GUE_NGL criticizes the issue’s reliance on top-down multiannual plans, inconsistent with their principle that socio-economic stability requires direct stakeholder co-management through Member States.  

GUE_NGL totally disapproves with the issue’s marginalization of regional governance, overlooking the necessity of localized adaptation to ensure both ecological sustainability and public fish supply.  

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s limited scope for Advisory Councils, which fails to guarantee meaningful sector involvement in aligning conservation with community development goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), emphasizing the need to restore fish stocks above maximum sustainable yield (MSY) through ecosystem-based approaches, technical measures, and multiannual plans. It highlighted challenges since 2009, including institutional tensions over decision-making powers under Article 43 TFEU and legislative delays, particularly regarding technical measures (e.g., driftnets, cetacean bycatches) and multiannual plans blocked for over three years. The resolution stressed the importance of simplifying and regionalizing technical measures to adapt to specific fisheries and basins, improve selectivity, minimize discards, and involve stakeholders via Advisory Councils, while ensuring alignment with CFP objectives and the Marine Strategy Framework Directive. It called for a clear EU-wide framework regulation to unify fragmented rules, repeal outdated regulations (e.g., Council Regulations 850/98 and 1967/2006), and promote innovation in selective gear, supported by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). The Parliament advocated for multiannual plans based on scientific and socio-economic data, incorporating MSY targets, precautionary safeguards, and review clauses, while limiting delegated acts on discard plans to three years. It underscored the landing obligation’s impact, urging flexibility in mesh sizes, catch composition rules, and gear diversity, and emphasized combating illegal fishing (IUU), particularly in the Mediterranean, through stricter enforcement. The resolution reaffirmed the ordinary legislative procedure for basin-wide rules and delegated acts for regional measures, retaining Parliament’s right to object, and stressed harmonizing marketing standards with conservation goals to ensure market integrity.

title: Community Fisheries Control Agency: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 768/2005 establishing a Community Fisheries Control Agency
background: Heightened Mediterranean migration flows and fragmented national coastguard authorities underscored challenges in maritime security, fisheries control, and border management. The Parliament will discuss amending the 2005 Community Fisheries Control Agency regulation to enhance EU agency cooperation in surveillance, information-sharing, and operational coordination across maritime sectors.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely accepts the issue's establishment of cross-agency cooperation frameworks, perfectly aligning with its commitment to integrated maritime security and crisis management.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the emphasis on advanced data-sharing systems, recognizing this as critical for preventing overlaps and strengthening Schengen-area border integrity.  
EPP entirely accepts maintaining strict adherence to agency competencies, ensuring member states' sovereign rights as coastal nations remain inviolable under the proposal.  
EPP highlights the issue's capacity-sharing mechanisms as effectively advancing its priority of resource-efficient, multi-dimensional operations against human trafficking and maritime emergencies.  
EPP fully supports the technology-driven surveillance mandate, which aligns perfectly with its longstanding advocacy for modernized EU-wide crisis response infrastructure.

ENF rejects the establishment of new EU agencies as outlined in the issue, citing the proposed Community Fisheries Control Agency as a "money-destroying machine" inconsistent with national sovereignty principles.  
ENF opposes fundamentally the imposition of EU deadlines on member states through liaison officers, deeming it an unacceptable erosion of national autonomy.  
The proposal totally doubts with ENF's stance against EU overreach, exemplified by the undemocratic handling of the report under Article 50 of procedural rules.  
The issue fails to address ENF's core concerns about facilitating illegal immigration through centralized border management, mirroring criticisms of Frontex operations.  
ENF condemns the disregard for national referendums like Brexit in pushing EU integration, viewing the issue as contradictory to popular sovereignty.

ALDE completely endorses the establishment of a European Border and Coast Guard Agency with integrated geolocation and surveillance systems, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to cross-sectoral maritime security and humanitarian crisis prevention.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on leveraging EMSA and EFCA expertise to dismantle human trafficking networks, ensuring advanced monitoring technologies prioritize life-saving interventions over border militarization.  
ALDE fully supports Amendment 1’s safeguards for inter-agency collaboration, which codify mission integrity while enabling data-sharing frameworks critical to addressing migration-driven maritime risks.  
ALDE applauds the proposal’s recognition of the new Border and Coast Guard Agency’s reliance on specialized agencies’ expertise, reflecting ALDE’s prioritization of capacity-sharing to combat illegal fishing and enhance search-and-rescue efficiency.  
ALDE underscores the issue’s alignment with its vision for multi-dimensional maritime operations, particularly the mandate for electronic reporting systems and risk management protocols to harmonize border security with environmental protection.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the integration of fisheries control resources into border surveillance frameworks, as this entrenches repressive migration policies contrary to human rights principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the creation of supranational coast guard structures that usurp member states' sovereignty over territorial waters, directly conflicting with their defense of national jurisdiction.  
GUE_NGL condemns the accelerated procedural manipulation used to advance this issue, which systematically excluded amendments safeguarding democratic oversight and migrant protections.  
GUE_NGL denounces the exploitation of migration flows to militarize EU agencies, a securitization agenda irreconcilable with their anti-Fortress Europe stance.  
GUE_NGL asserts that merging EMSA and fisheries control with Frontex consolidates a security-industrial complex antithetical to social justice and ecological stewardship priorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of its position on a Commission proposal aimed at enhancing maritime safety, security, and cooperation through integrated surveillance systems. The resolution emphasized the need for EU agencies and member states to share information and establish advanced technology-driven surveillance and communication services to improve cross-sectoral operations. It prioritized capacity-building at both EU and national levels to address challenges in maritime safety, security, search and rescue, fisheries control, and border control. Additionally, the resolution advocated for capacity-sharing initiatives, including cross-border and cross-sectoral asset sharing, to enable coordinated, multi-dimensional maritime operations. Parliament also instructed its President to communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, while urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments to the proposal are planned.

title: Conformity of fisheries products with access criteria to the EU market: REPORT on the implementation of control measures for establishing the conformity of fisheries products with access criteria to the EU market
background: The European Union, as the world’s largest importer of fisheries products, faces challenges in ensuring third-country imports meet its environmental, labor, and safety standards due to uneven ratification of international conventions by member states and varying compliance levels. The Parliament will discuss aligning market access criteria for imported fisheries products with EU regulations to address competitive disparities and promote global sustainability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts ensuring imported fisheries products meet equivalent EU standards, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fair competition and sustainable trade practices.  
EPP approves the issue's call for fully harmonized import controls across member states to eliminate regulatory loopholes and protect EU fishers from unfair competition.  
EPP proposes introducing a mandatory EU-specific labeling system to clearly distinguish products meeting the bloc's high environmental and labor standards, enhancing consumer transparency.  
EPP emphasizes reinforcing youth engagement programs through dedicated funding for vocational training and modernized fishing technologies to address sectoral workforce challenges.  
EPP endorses expanding the EUMOFA's analytical mandate to track third-country compliance with international conventions, ensuring coherence between trade policy and sustainability goals.

SD firmly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on equitable market access for ultraperipheral regions, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to territorial cohesion and fair competition in fisheries value chains.  
SD perfectly aligns with calls to restore dedicated financial instruments like POSEI pescas, recognizing their critical role in enabling sustainable commercial fishing in geographically disadvantaged areas.  
SD fully supports the issue’s demand for strict parity between EU and third-country product standards, particularly in enhancing traceability labeling and binding trade clauses to eliminate unfair advantages from lax labor or environmental practices.  
SD strongly endorses harmonized enforcement of IUU Regulation controls across supply chains, emphasizing the need to prioritize EFCA’s operational capacity for uniform inspections as a cornerstone of market integrity.  
SD applauds the focus on small-scale fisheries’ viability through producer organizations and reduced intermediation, which directly advances SD’s agenda for equitable remuneration and localized value chains.

ECR supports the issue's emphasis on aligning import criteria with EU labor and environmental standards to ensure fair competition for European fishers.  
ECR advises enhancing labeling requirements to explicitly mandate vessel flag state disclosure and EU/non-EU origin differentiation across all fisheries products.  
ECR urges the Commission to reconsider Adriatic small pelagic fish quota proposals, arguing current restrictions risk destabilizing local processing chains dependent on anchovy and sardine supplies.  
ECR emphasizes strict enforcement of IUU Regulation controls while advocating EFCA reinforcement to standardize port inspections and catch documentation.  
ECR advocates reducing administrative burdens for small-scale fishers through simplified producer organization rules to strengthen local market access.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to mandate binding EU-wide price controls on first-sale fisheries products, firmly conflicting with their demand for equitable income redistribution to small-scale fishers.  

GUE_NGL opposes the inadequate measures against intermediary dominance in supply chains, overlooking critical aspects such as capping profit margins for wholesalers as outlined in their 2023 Coastal Communities Manifesto.  

The proposal firmly conflicts with GUE_NGL's principle of public financing guarantees for artisanal fleets, lacking enforceable mechanisms to stabilize fishermen’s incomes amid volatile import competition.  

GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s prioritization of third-country import standards while neglecting structural EU market reforms, inconsistent with their focus on dismantling neoliberal trade distortions in coastal economies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over disparities in labor, safety, and sustainability standards between EU and third-country fisheries products, noting that 25 Member States ratified the Maritime Labour Convention for seafarers, while only 3 ratified ILO Convention 188 for fishers, with gaps in enforcement and exclusion of self-employed fishers. Vessel safety standards under the Cape Town Agreement (ratified by 11 MS) apply only to vessels over 24m, and training conventions like STCW-F for fishers (6 MS) remain unincorporated into EU law, urging the Commission to prioritize TFEU Article 155 procedures. Highlighting the EU’s role as the world’s largest fisheries market (absorbing 24% of global imports in 2016, with 60% dependency on imports), the resolution stressed the need for imported products to meet EU environmental, labor, and sanitary standards to ensure fair competition and sustainability. It criticized lax import controls, particularly under the IUU Regulation, and called for stricter harmonized enforcement across supply chains, enhanced third-country inspections, and binding trade agreement clauses requiring ratification of key international instruments (e.g., UN Fish Stocks Agreement, FAO Port State Measures). The resolution urged improved labeling for traceability, including vessel flag states, and stricter due diligence requirements akin to timber and conflict minerals. It emphasized reinforcing the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA) to ensure uniform inspections, data transparency, and sanctions, while opposing any weakening of the IUU Regulation. The Parliament also highlighted incoherence between trade and fisheries policies, advocating exclusion of non-compliant third countries from market access and post-Brexit reciprocity linking UK market access to CFP compliance.

title: Conservation of fishery resources and protection of marine ecosystems through technical measures: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conservation of fishery resources and the protection of marine ecosystems through technical measures, amending Council Regulations (EC) No 1967/2006, (EC) No 1098/2007, (EC) No 1224/2009 and Regulations (EU) No 1343/2011 and (EU) No 1380/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and repealing Council Regulations (EC) No 894/97, (EC) No 850/98, (EC) No 2549/2000, (EC) No 254/2002, (EC) No 812/2004 and (EC) No 2187/2005
background: The European Union's technical measures regulating fishing methods, established through multiple overlapping regulations since 1998, faced criticism for complexity and insufficient alignment with post-2013 Common Fisheries Policy sustainability goals. The Parliament will discuss consolidating and modernizing these rules to improve marine ecosystem protection while addressing regional fishing sector operational realities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the regionalization framework for gear specifications and closed areas, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to adaptive fisheries management that respects ecological and economic diversity across sea basins.  
EPP approves the provisional 5% fleet limit for experimental pulse fishing in the North Sea, proposing enhanced scientific oversight through mandated EU institute collaboration to address ecological concerns while preserving innovation pathways.  
EPP advocates strict enforcement mechanisms for juvenile fish protection thresholds, converting opposition to non-selective methods into a call for real-time bycatch monitoring systems under Article 4(2).  
EPP emphasizes safeguarding artisanal fisheries through Adriatic-specific net-depth exemptions, effectively advancing EPP's priority of balancing employment stability with seabed preservation as per Croatia’s case-study amendments.  
 EPP acknowledges divergent views on pulse fishing but consolidates support for the rapporteur’s compromise, urging the Council to adopt Article 9’s four-year review clause to reassess environmental impacts.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to comprehensively ban electric fishing, which fully condemns with their mandate to prevent ecosystem destruction and protect artisanal fisheries.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the regionalization framework as anarchic and inconsistent with their demand for binding numerical targets to measure marine conservation progress.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposal's allowance of non-scientific exemptions for destructive practices, directly violating their evidence-based governance principles.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's disregard for coastal community safeguards, overlooking critical linkages between industrial fishing methods and socioeconomic collapse.  
GREEN_EFA demands full accountability for the Commission's flawed impact assessments on gear specifications, which perpetuate systemic overexploitation.

SD strongly advocates the regionalization approach to technical measures, aligning with SD's commitment to adaptive fisheries management that respects local ecosystems.  
SD approves the emphasis on reducing bycatch through gear specifications and urges enhanced data collection to protect juvenile fish populations.  
SD proposes strengthening Article 4 to implement a complete ban on electric fishing, ensuring alignment with precautionary scientific advice.  
SD endorses multi-annual regional plans as critical for balancing legislative flexibility with parliamentary oversight in ecosystem protection.  
SD highlights the need for simplified regulations to reduce administrative burdens while maintaining strict conservation targets across all maritime basins.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposal's failure to institute an immediate ban on electric pulse fishing, which contradicts our mandate to prevent irreversible marine ecosystem damage as evidenced by vertebral fractures and hemorrhaging in cod.  
GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the continued subsidization of industrial bottom-trawling fleets through loopholes in amended Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013, enabling the "race to the seabed" denounced in Article 4's gear specifications.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's omission of binding measures against static/drift nets causing cetacean bycatch, directly conflicting with our amendments to prohibit such gear under Chapter III's closed-area provisions.  
GUE/NGL disputes the regionalization framework as centralization masquerading as reform, disproportionately burdening small-scale fisheries (addressed only superficially in Recital 9) while privileging northern industrial interests.  
GUE/NGL declares the proposal inconsistent with maximum sustainable yield objectives by permitting juvenile fish mortality through unrevised mesh-size rules in Article 2(7), undermining the 2020 deadline.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading, adopting the resolution that underscores the need for sustainable fisheries management and aligns with the Commission’s 2016 proposal (COM(2016)0134) to revise technical measures for conservation and ecosystem protection. It emphasizes reducing bycatch, safeguarding juvenile fish, and minimizing environmental impacts through gear specifications, closed areas, and seasonal closures, while ensuring flexibility for regional adaptations. The resolution stresses adherence to the Common Fisheries Policy’s objectives, including achieving maximum sustainable yield by 2020, and calls for enhanced data collection and stakeholder collaboration. It urges the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended and instructs the Parliament’s President to forward its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring coherence with EU environmental and health policies.

title: Establishing a multi-annual plan for the fisheries exploiting demersal stocks in the western Mediterranean Sea: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multi-annual plan for the fisheries exploiting demersal stocks in the western Mediterranean Sea

The 2016 MedFish4Ever Declaration prioritized regional fisheries sustainability, prompting the European Commission’s 2018 proposal for a management framework aligning with Common Fisheries Policy objectives. The Parliament will discuss establishing a multi-annual plan to regulate demersal fisheries in the western Mediterranean.

EPP strongly advocates the multi-annual plan's alignment with sustainability goals while proposing enhanced regional flexibility in trawl restriction implementation.  
EPP recommends adjusting the three-month trawl closure period based on localized scientific assessments to address sector-specific operational realities.  
EPP emphasizes the need for compensatory measures for auxiliary industries affected by effort reductions, ensuring socioeconomic cohesion in coastal communities.  
EPP applauds the inclusion of co-management frameworks as consistent with its principles of subsidiarity and stakeholder collaboration.

GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the delayed MSY targets as incompatible with scientific urgency to halt 4-5× overfishing of demersal stocks.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the five-year sustainability postponement, violating their 2018 manifesto requirement for immediate ecosystem-based catch limits.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the plan's failure to mandate spatial closures or binding fleet reduction, contradicting Verts/ALE amendments on effort management.  
GREEN_EFA condemns reliance on voluntary co-management without EU compensation mechanisms for Catalonia-style transition programs.  
GREEN_EFA deems the "weak starting point" approach inconsistent with precautionary principle obligations under Mediterranean RFMO agreements.

ALDE rejects the proposal’s incremental effort reductions as inconsistent with urgent scientific warnings requiring immediate 50% catch cuts to prevent stock collapse.  
ALDE highlights contradictions with ALDE’s environmental principles, noting the plan overlooks critical protections for coastal ecosystems from trawling impacts.  
ALDE condemns the issue’s lack of enforceable penalties for non-compliance by member states, undermining recovery goals.  
ALDE demands amendments to Article 4 to mandate full closure of trawling in nursery zones year-round, not just seasonal restrictions.

SD strongly advocates the balanced multi-annual plan as a critical step toward achieving the Common Fisheries Policy’s sustainability goals for demersal stocks. This aligns perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to reconciling ecological preservation with fishing community viability.  

SD applauds the issue’s emphasis on regional collaboration between Member States and advisory councils to implement tailored conservation measures. The proposal effectively advances SD’s priority of context-sensitive fisheries management in the Mediterranean.  

SD endorses the integration of environmental, social, and economic sustainability, particularly the recognition of local fleets’ adaptive practices. This mirrors SD’s advocacy for policies that prevent irreversible socioeconomic harm to coastal regions.  

SD proposes enhancing flexibility in trawling ban implementation by allowing compensatory measures for permanent fleet reductions, ensuring proportionality between conservation goals and livelihood protection.  

SD emphasizes the need to strengthen cooperation with non-EU Mediterranean states through the General Fisheries Commission framework to ensure cross-border stock management aligns with the issue’s objectives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0115), informed by the Committee on Fisheries’ report and the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee’s amendments (A8-0005/2019), alongside the European Economic and Social Committee’s July 2018 opinion. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial changes are made and instructed its President to forward the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments.

title: European Maritime and Fisheries Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and repealing Regulation (EU) No 508/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council
background: The European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (2014-2020) faced implementation challenges, including sustainable fisheries management under the Common Fisheries Policy, fleet capacity constraints, and post-Brexit resource allocation uncertainties. The Commission proposed a €6.14 billion EMFF renewal (2021-2027) within the Multiannual Financial Framework. The Parliament will discuss the fund’s budgetary priorities, operational reforms, and alignment with EU sustainability goals.

stances.stance:
