EFDD fully challenges the issue’s ambiguous eligibility restrictions in Section 2.3, demanding amendments to exempt minor fisheries violations from funding bans, which it deems disproportionate to practical operational realities.  
This conflicts with EFDD’s principle of prioritising fishers’ economic survival over rigid environmental conditionalities, as the issue inadequately safeguards temporary fishing halt subsidies in Clause 5a against arbitrary discontinuation.  
EFDD conditionally endorses vessel modernization support yet insists on deleting age-based eligibility criteria in Annex III, arguing these discriminate against older fishers contrary to equitable regional development goals.  
The proposal overlooks critical risk-mitigation measures, prompting EFDD to demand explicit provisions in Article 9 for advance insurance payouts during natural disasters, aligning with their emphasis on rapid crisis response for maritime workers.

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposed EMFF regulation for maintaining provisions that permit increased fishing capacity despite documented overexploitation of 80% Mediterranean stocks, completely opposeing with ecosystem protection mandates.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the 10% budget allocation for environmental monitoring as structurally inadequate compared to their demanded 25% minimum for meaningful biodiversity conservation.  
The proposal's failure to prohibit fleet modernization subsidies in overfished regions directly violates GREEN_EFA's principle of science-based fisheries management.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's implicit acceptance of delayed CFP sustainability objectives as inconsistent with six years of documented policy failures.  
The absence of binding mechanisms to phase out destructive fishing practices contradicts GREEN_EFA's core commitment to marine ecosystem restoration.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on sustainable fisheries management and environmental protection, aligning perfectly with their commitment to EU sustainability goals and integrated marine policies.  
ALDE approves the prioritization of equitable regional development through targeted budgetary allocations, particularly for vulnerable coastal communities and ultra-peripheral regions like the Canary Islands.  
ALDE proposes enhancing funding criteria to ensure structural support reaches regions requiring transition to sustainable practices, rather than islands with established sustainability frameworks.  
ALDE endorses modernizing fishing fleets through decarbonization and innovation investments that reduce discards and improve safety, provided capacity limits are strictly maintained.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need to integrate maritime ecosystem health into funding decisions, reinforcing their principle that ocean protection underpins long-term fishing viability.

SD strongly upholds the mandated minimum 25% EMFF allocations for marine biodiversity protection and fisheries control systems, directly advancing SD's environmental stewardship priorities.  
SD approves the permanent capacity reduction mechanisms with repayment safeguards for resumed fishing activities, ensuring alignment with sustainable stock management goals.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 12 to include specific credit access programs for small-scale Mediterranean fishers while maintaining the issue's core accountability framework.  
SD endorses the issue's emphasis on ultra-peripheral regions through increased budgetary ring-fencing, consistent with SD's regional equity commitments in maritime policy.  
SD applauds the transparency requirements for member-state expenditure reporting as critical to preventing fund misuse, a key pillar of SD's 2024 fisheries reform agenda.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0390) concerning fisheries, environmental, budgetary, and regional policies, emphasizing alignment with EU treaties and sustainable development goals. It adopted amendments to strengthen measures for sustainable fisheries management, environmental protection, and equitable regional development, while ensuring coherence with existing EU legislation. The resolution underscored the need for robust budgetary allocations to support these objectives, particularly in vulnerable regions, and called for enhanced cooperation between member states and EU institutions. Parliament urged the Commission to prioritize transparency and stakeholder consultation, particularly with the Committee on Fisheries and other relevant committees, and to integrate recommendations from the Committee of the Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee. It insisted that any substantial revision or replacement of the proposal by the Commission must be resubmitted to Parliament for further scrutiny, ensuring legislative continuity and democratic accountability. The resolution also mandated the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional dialogue.

title: Optimisation of the value chain in the EU fishing sector: REPORT on the optimisation of the value chain in the EU fishing sector

SD applauds the integration of gender-inclusive policies and youth training programs, which mirror SD’s 2023 manifesto pledges on social equity and future-proofing the sector.

ECR strongly approves the issue's emphasis on equal import standards, aligning perfectly with ECR's commitment to fair competition and protecting EU fisheries from third-country market distortions.  
ECR approves enhanced labeling rules to disclose vessel flags and origin, proposing to expand mandatory coverage beyond current limited product categories as a market transparency enhancement.  
ECR endorses reducing bureaucratic burdens for producer organizations, noting this directly advances their priority of empowering coastal communities through streamlined local fish distribution.  
ECR highlights the need to balance Adriatic small pelagic quotas with ecosystem-based management, suggesting the Commission collaborate with national bodies to avoid destabilizing Croatia’s processing chain.  
ECR applauds gender-inclusive policies and youth training programs as critical to sectoral resilience, mirroring their 2023 manifesto on revitalizing maritime economies through workforce investment.

GUE_NGL totally upholds the issue's prioritization of equitable value distribution through binding mechanisms to reduce intermediary margins, perfectly aligning with their advocacy for worker-centric economic models in coastal communities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about disparities in the implementation of fisheries controls across Member States, emphasizing the need for harmonized, non-discriminatory enforcement of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) to ensure sustainable resource management and a level playing field. It highlighted operational challenges, including inconsistent inspection protocols, divergent sanctions for infringements, and gaps in monitoring foreign vessels and imported fishery products, particularly from illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing. The resolution stressed the importance of strengthening the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA) through increased resources, standardized training for inspectors via a core curriculum, and enhanced cooperation between Member States, including data sharing and joint inspections. It called for leveraging the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF)—noting its €580 million allocation for 2014–2020—to modernize control technologies, such as electronic logbooks and remote tracking systems, while opposing mandatory onboard video surveillance. The Parliament urged addressing inequities in the landing obligation, advocating flexibility for multi-species fisheries and extending the two-year adaptation period for compliance. It emphasized harmonizing sanctions, promoting economic penalties over criminal ones, and ensuring transparency in enforcement to build trust. Additional measures included stricter import controls, mandatory traceability in restaurants, and expanded EFCA authority to oversee overexploited fisheries. The resolution underscored the need for simplified, enforceable regulations, risk-based inspections, and equitable application of rules across all maritime zones, including outermost regions, to safeguard fisheries-dependent communities and promote sustainable practices.

It stressed the need to maintain fish stocks above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield (MSY) by 2020, aligning with FAO guidelines, and highlighted the EU’s responsibility to ensure equitable access for developing coastal states to adjacent fisheries resources through regional fisheries management organizations (RFMOs). The resolution called for enhanced transparency in Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (SFPAs), including public disclosure of access terms and catches, and urged harmonizing conditions for foreign fleets in African waters to promote fair competition. It underscored the EU’s role in combating illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing through rigorous enforcement of the IUU Regulation and advocated for improved scientific data collection, particularly in developing countries, to assess surplus stocks. The Parliament emphasized support for small-scale fisheries, gender equality in the sector, and sectoral aid to partner countries for infrastructure, scientific capacity, and food security, while ensuring policy coherence with development goals. It criticized private agreements between EU shipowners and third countries that bypass CFP standards, urging regulatory frameworks for joint ventures to prevent unfair competition with local artisanal fleets. The resolution also highlighted the EU’s market influence, noting it consumes 11% of global fish production by volume and imports 24% by value, and called for trade agreements to enforce sustainability and labor standards. Finally, it advocated for regional management of shared stocks, expanded marine protected areas, and increased funding for RFMOs to strengthen global fisheries governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the unique challenges faced by the EU’s outermost regions (ORs) in fisheries management, emphasizing their geographic remoteness, socio-economic vulnerabilities, and high unemployment (up to 60% youth unemployment in some regions). It highlighted the ORs’ reliance on small-scale, traditional fishing fleets, which are often outdated, posing safety risks and hindering competitiveness, and noted that their exclusive economic zones (EEZs)—covering 2.5 million km², equivalent to the EU’s continental EEZs—are under pressure from illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing and external fleets. The resolution stressed the need for tailored policies under Article 349 TFEU, which permits derogations from EU rules to address OR-specific challenges, and criticized the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) for insufficient flexibility to support OR fisheries, despite existing measures like 100% EMFF subsidies for additional costs and a 35% increase in aid intensity for certain projects. It called for enhanced scientific data collection to inform sustainable fishing opportunities, exclusive access for OR-registered vessels in OR waters, modernization of aging fleets (without increasing capacity), and the creation of a dedicated fisheries fund modeled on the POSEI agricultural scheme. The Parliament also urged stronger EU action against IUU fishing, improved synergies between EU funds to boost local economies, and impact assessments for fisheries agreements affecting ORs. Additionally, it emphasized food security through local fisheries and advocated for simplified regulations to facilitate access to funding and infrastructure investments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities regarding the EU-Guinea-Bissau Fisheries Partnership Agreement, emphasizing the need for sustainable, mutually beneficial cooperation. The resolution highlighted fishing opportunities granted to EU fleets, including 3,700 GRT for shrimp trawlers, 3,500 GRT for fin-fish/cephalopod trawlers, 28 tuna seiners/longliners, and 12 pole-and-line vessels, while stressing the importance of limiting access to surplus stocks to ensure ecological sustainability and local food security. It noted financial contributions under the Agreement as a significant part of Guinea-Bissau’s budget but criticized past suspensions of sectoral support due to poor aid uptake and insufficient local economic benefits, with only 148 local crew jobs and minimal processing infrastructure (one plant in 2010). The resolution urged enhanced transparency, accountability, and participation of artisanal fishing communities, advocating for technical assistance to strengthen institutional capacity, vocational training, gender inclusion (recognizing women’s roles in distribution and processing), and partnerships to boost local fisheries’ added value. It called for stricter measures against illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing, citing 58 non-compliant vessels in 2008–2009, and emphasized improved monitoring via satellite systems, logbooks, and regional cooperation. The Parliament demanded better data collection on catches and resource sustainability, regular Joint Committee oversight to address corruption risks, and alignment of sectoral support with development funds like the European Development Fund. It insisted on Guinea-Bissau’s compliance with EU health standards to facilitate trade and urged the Commission to ensure regular reporting, including annual assessments of the sectoral program and full implementation reviews before Protocol renewal.

resolution: The European Parliament raised substantive amendments to several EU fisheries regulations to enhance conservation and management, focusing on the Baltic Sea, Mediterranean, and deep-sea stocks. Key changes included deleting ambiguous provisions in Council Regulations 850/98 and 2187/2005 that required fishing vessel captains to hold sufficient quotas, deemed unenforceable. It opposed altering logbook rules under Article 14 of Regulation 1224/2009, arguing existing provisions should remain to avoid complicating the landing obligation. The Parliament simplified remote electronic monitoring requirements in Article 25a of Regulation 1224/2009, affirming member states’ autonomy in monitoring methods and clarifying that the regulation does not mandate widespread remote surveillance. It also proposed removing Article 49a of Regulation 1224/2009, which required separate storage for undersized catches, deeming it unnecessarily burdensome for fishermen and non-essential for enforcing landing obligations. The resolution addressed diverse fisheries, including small and large pelagic species, industrial fisheries (e.g., capelin, sandeel), Baltic salmon, and other Baltic fisheries, while referencing foundational regulations such as 1967/2006 (Mediterranean management), 1098/2007 (Baltic cod plan), and 2347/2002 (deep-sea access rules). The Parliament emphasized aligning technical measures with sustainability goals and simplifying compliance for stakeholders.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and established measures to enhance transparency and accountability in EU fisheries management, mandating the Commission to annually report on the alignment between scientific advice and Council decisions regarding fishing opportunities. Additionally, a seven-year sunset clause was introduced for management provisions directly tied to updated scientific advice, ensuring legislators can review and amend the framework post-deadline. The resolution emphasized maintaining scientific integrity in decision-making, institutional oversight, and periodic evaluation of regulatory mechanisms, while instructing the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to its original proposal.

title: Multiannual plan for small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council  establishing a multi-annual plan for small pelagic stocks in the Adriatic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks

title: Multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks, amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005 and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1098/2007

title: Multiannual recovery plan for Bluefin tuna: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for Bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean repealing Regulation (EC) No 302/2009

title: North-East Atlantic: deep-sea stocks and fishing in international waters: RECOMMENDATION FOR SECOND READING on the Council position at first reading in view of the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing specific conditions for fishing for deep-sea stocks in the North-East Atlantic and provisions for fishing in international waters of the North-East Atlantic and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2347/2002

title: Small-scale coastal fishing in regions dependent on fishing: REPORT on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in fisheries-dependent regions

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of small-scale coastal fishing, which constitutes 80% of the EU fleet and sustains employment in coastal, island, and outermost regions, emphasizing its socio-economic, cultural, and environmental sustainability. It called for revising the EU definition of small-scale coastal fishing (currently limited to vessels under 12 meters not using towed gear) to reflect regional diversity, including vessel size, fishing techniques, and traditional practices, and urged leveraging the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) to prioritize funding for this sector, including a 30% aid intensity increase for eligible projects. The resolution stressed the need to address challenges such as declining revenues, rising operational costs, competition from non-EU fleets, and marginalization of women in auxiliary roles, advocating for gender-inclusive policies, recognition of women’s contributions, and support for diversification into tourism, gastronomy, and cultural heritage initiatives. It highlighted the vulnerability of outermost regions, proposing tailored EMFF measures akin to the POSEI agricultural scheme to offset higher costs and aging fleets, while promoting sustainable aquaculture and marine protected areas. The Parliament urged harmonizing technical measures with regional needs, easing administrative burdens (e.g., logbook flexibility for vessels under 12 meters), and ensuring fair quota allocation for non-industrial fisheries. It emphasized blue growth through innovation, research under Horizon 2020, and public-private partnerships, while safeguarding traditional fishing methods like almadraba traps. Environmental sustainability was underscored via stricter impact assessments, combating illegal fishing, and integrating coastal communities into maritime governance through Fisheries Local Action Groups (FLAGs). The resolution also advocated for marine knowledge expansion, data transparency, and alignment of Mediterranean fishing regulations with the Common Fisheries Policy’s regionalization principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the critical status of European sea bass stocks, highlighting insufficient scientific data on stock boundaries, migration, and spawning areas, particularly across four identified regions (Celtic Sea/Channel/North Sea, Bay of Biscay, Western Iberian waters, and West of Scotland/Ireland). Despite emergency measures like the 2015 pelagic trawl ban in key areas, mortality remains high, threatening recovery of this slow-growing, economically vital species, with recreational fisheries contributing at least 25% of total catches. Noting the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries’ recommendation for a 60% reduction in fishing mortality, Parliament urged the Commission and Member States to develop a multiannual EU management plan aligned with Common Fisheries Policy goals to restore stocks above maximum sustainable yield. This plan should include scientifically informed measures such as potential total allowable catches (TACs), spatio-temporal closures during spawning, minimum landing sizes, and coherent limits for both commercial and recreational sectors. Emphasizing regionalized, stakeholder-inclusive approaches, Parliament called for enhanced data collection via EU funding and stressed the necessity of reconciling divergent national measures to ensure sustainable exploitation and equitable resource access.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the critical state of marine biodiversity, noting that 71% of Earth’s surface is ocean, with 64% beyond national jurisdiction, yet less than 1% of these areas are protected. It emphasized the urgent need for a legally binding international agreement under UNCLOS to address gaps in conserving marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction (ABNJ), aiming to finalize the draft by 2017. The resolution highlighted the decline of marine ecosystems due to overfishing, climate change, pollution, and unregulated activities like deep-sea mining, stressing that only 8.4% of global marine areas are protected. It called for ecosystem-based management, marine protected areas (MPAs), and the application of Ecologically or Biologically Significant Marine Areas (EBSAs), of which 204 have been identified, many in ABNJ. The EU was urged to lead in combating illegal fishing, promoting sustainable fisheries, and addressing plastic marine litter, while supporting developing nations through capacity-building and technology transfer. The resolution underscored the need for environmental impact assessments for high-sea activities, improved scientific data (noting 80% of EU marine species remain unclassified), and enhanced coordination among regional bodies like RFMOs. It advocated for a global vessel registry to combat IUU fishing and stressed that the new agreement must complement existing frameworks like the UN Fish Stocks Agreement without undermining them, ensuring equitable access and safeguarding marine biodiversity for future generations.

background: The EU Common Fisheries Policy requires Member States to allocate fishing quotas using transparent, objective environmental, social, and economic criteria, but implementation varies, with reported gaps in transparency and equitable access for small-scale fisheries. resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the lack of transparency and inconsistent application of environmental, social, and economic criteria in EU Member States’ allocation of fishing opportunities under the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), particularly Article 17 of Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013. It highlighted that only 16 out of 23 coastal Member States provided information on their allocation methods in 2020, often with vague or incomplete details, and stressed the need for Member States to publish clear, objective criteria to ensure fairness and sustainability. The resolution noted that historical catch levels remain the dominant allocation criterion, which risks economic concentration and barriers for new entrants, while incentives for low-impact fishing practices are underutilized. It emphasized the importance of supporting small-scale coastal fisheries, citing disparities in bluefin tuna quotas (e.g., 3.03% allocated to small-scale vessels in Italy vs. 36.93% in Spain) and urged Member States to prioritize environmental sustainability, social equity, and generational renewal, including using the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) to aid young fishers. The Parliament criticized the EU’s failure to meet the 2020 deadline for achieving good marine environmental status and maximum sustainable yield (MSY) for all stocks, despite progress in regions like the north-east Atlantic (99% of landings from sustainably managed stocks in 2020). It called on the Commission to enforce compliance with Article 17, initiate infringement procedures against non-transparent Member States, and develop guidelines and impact assessments to align quota allocations with biodiversity and climate goals, including voluntary targets for environmentally sustainable fishing. The resolution also urged addressing legislative gaps to implement international fisheries agreements and ensure equitable access to marine resources in line with UN Sustainable Development Goals.

background: Persistent overfishing in Mediterranean and Black Seas, unmet 2020 EU targets for sustainable fish stocks under the Common Fisheries Policy and Marine Strategy Framework Directive, and biodiversity objectives for 30% protected marine areas by 2030 prompted action. resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over ongoing overfishing, noting that 38% of North-East Atlantic and 92% of Mediterranean and Black Sea stocks remain overexploited, despite legal obligations to end overfishing by 2020. It highlighted progress in the North-East Atlantic, where 99% of landings now derive from sustainably managed fisheries, with biomass increasing by 48% since 2003. The resolution called for full implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), including setting total allowable catches (TACs) at maximum sustainable yield (MSY) levels, expanding scientific assessments to cover 100% of exploited stocks by 2025, and improving data collection, particularly in underassessed regions like the Black Sea and Mediterranean. It urged stronger ecosystem-based management, including multi-species approaches, limits on destructive fishing gear, and support for small-scale fisheries, which are deemed more sustainable. The Parliament emphasized expanding marine protected areas (MPAs) to 30% of EU seas by 2030, with 10% strictly protected, and ensuring effective management plans, stakeholder involvement, and science-based guidelines. It stressed addressing climate change, pollution (e.g., plastics, nitrates, and industrial waste), and promoting ocean resilience, while advocating for fishermen’s role in waste recovery. The resolution also demanded transparency in TAC decisions, alignment with international biodiversity goals, and global cooperation to protect marine biodiversity beyond national jurisdictions.

title: Multiannual management plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual management plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, amending Regulations (EC) No 1936/2001, (EU) 2017/2107, and (EU) 2019/833 and repealing Regulation (EU) 2016/1627 | A9-0149/2020 | European Parliament

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to align EU regulations with updated International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) recommendations, particularly 18-02 and 19-04, to ensure sustainable bluefin tuna management. Key amendments included transitioning from a rebuilding plan to a long-term management plan for bluefin tuna while maintaining strict monitoring and control measures, addressing by-catch quotas for fishers targeting species like swordfish who lack dedicated bluefin tuna allocations, and allowing Member States to carry over up to 10% of unused annual bluefin tuna quotas to subsequent years. The resolution emphasized harmonizing definitions (e.g., "sport fishery," "fishing effort") with ICCAT standards to ensure clarity and enforceability, incorporating derogations for joint fishing operations under specific protocols, and requiring annual caging reports from Member States to improve transparency. It stressed that adjustments to fishing mortality targets must follow the ordinary legislative procedure to uphold the Common Fisheries Policy’s maximum sustainable yield (MSY) objectives, while ensuring coherence with ICCAT’s scientific advice and addressing operational challenges in mixed fisheries.
